pkgmetadata.longdescription: The purpose of this ebuild fork was originally to provide multilib support for the ebuild fork for the surf web browser on the oiledmachine-overlay. Currently the motivations are to provide latest stable as quickly as possible for security reasons and expose more options related to performance or next generation of web standards.

use.flag: Uses 64k pages but reduces security and performance. It also disables JIT and WebAssembly.
Enables AVIF support for testing.
Uses a mmap based page allocator to improve overall performance. Disable to use the system allocator.
Enable code coverage support
Enable EGL support
Install the MiniBrowser example application
Builds with the teir that does the bulk of the optimizing.
Builds an additional tier for JIT used for optimizing run-time performance marginally at the expense of faster load times or delayed execution time.
Enable gamepad input support via dev-libs/libmanette
Enable geolocation support through app-misc/geoclue
Enable GLESv2 support
Enable HTTP/2 support
Use ThinLTO LTO [link time optimization] when when linking. ThinLTO is used instead of full for efficient multicore and memory usage.
Ensures less problems with hardened build.
Enables JIT support for JavaScriptCore for significantly faster code execution. Disable for increased compatibility on alternative ARCHs and ABIs
Combine source files to speed up build process
Enables support for MediaStream API (IN DEVELOPMENT / DRAFT).
Enable full nsplugin support (GTK2 plugins)
Use OpenMP to accelerate SVG filters
Check dependencies for variation font support
Build support for the WebGL HTML API using virtual/opengl
Enables support for WebAssembly used for example in web games. Disable to decrease the attack surface.
Enables the B3 JIT support that does additional optimizations beyond ftl-jit.
Enables WebCrypto SubtleCrypto API support for low level cryptographic fuctions
Builds WebXR support. (EXPERIMENTAL / IN DEVELOPMENT)
Enables WebRTC support. (WebKitGTK EXPERIMENTAL, WebKit supported)
Enables JIT regex support. Otherwise, it falls back to interpretive
